misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Solving a different problem (distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program that reads two points and computes the distance between them, instead of reading a numeric grade (0-100) and printing the corresponding letter grade. As a result, there is no letter-grade logic or output at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads x1, y1, x2, y2 and prints the distance between the two points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read a single numeric grade from 0 to 100 and use if/else conditions to map that grade into a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F), then print the letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade.
Program computes `distance` using the distance formula.
Program output is the distance between two points, not a letter grade.
No branch in the code ever prints a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reuse of a solution from a different exercise about distance between two points, without adapting it to the grade-calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and redesign the program: remove the distance-related inputs and computation, read a single numeric grade, and implement an if/else-if chain that maps each numeric range to a letter grade and prints it.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All inputs, computations, and outputs are about point distances; there is no code related to letter grades or grade ranges.

evidence.note: Prompts for x1 and y1 and reads them, which is unrelated to the required grade input.
Prompts for x2 and y2 and reads them, again matching a distance problem rather than a single numeric grade.

evidence.snippet: double distance = Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2));
evidence.note: Computes the distance between two points, which is not part of the required grade-calculator algorithm.
Both branches print the distance between points; no branch prints a letter grade like 'A', 'B', etc.

misconceptions.name: Hard-coding the grade instead of reading it from the user
misconceptions.description: The student assigns a constant value to the grade variable (85) rather than reading the grade from keyboard input using Scanner, so the user can never enter their own grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can just set `int grade = 85;` in the code instead of reading a grade from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user to enter a numeric grade and then read that value from the keyboard using Scanner (e.g., `int grade = input.nextInt();`). Hard-coding a grade does not satisfy the requirement to read user input.
symptoms: Grade is given a fixed value of 85 inside the program.
There is no prompt or Scanner call that reads a grade from the user.
Changing user input has no effect on the grade being evaluated.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between using literals for quick testing and actually reading values from input as specified in the problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded line `int grade = 85;` with a prompt like `System.out.print("Enter grade: ");` followed by `int grade = input.nextInt();` so the grade comes from keyboard input.
related_concepts: Difference between constants and user input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is an explicit hard-coded assignment to `grade` and no corresponding input prompt or `nextInt()` call for the grade.

evidence.snippet: int grade = 85;
evidence.note: The grade is set to a constant 85 instead of being read from the keyboard.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using '&' instead of '&&' in a boolean condition
misconceptions.description: In the if condition that checks the grade range, the student uses the single ampersand operator '&' instead of the short-circuit logical AND operator '&&'. While it happens to work with simple boolean expressions, it suggests confusion between bitwise and logical operators.
misconceptions.student_belief: The '&' operator is the standard way to combine boolean conditions, equivalent to '&&'.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, '&&' is the usual logical AND operator for boolean conditions in if statements; it short-circuits and is clearer for control flow. '&' can be used on booleans but is typically for bitwise operations on integers and does not short-circuit.
symptoms: Condition is written with '&' instead of '&&'.
Could cause unintended evaluation of the right-hand side in more complex conditions.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators and logical operators, or not being aware of the difference between '&' and '&&' in Java.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace '&' with '&&' in the condition: `if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90) { ... }`. Review the difference between bitwise operators ('&', '|') and logical operators ('&&', '||') in Java.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student uses '&' in a typical boolean range check where '&&' is standard, which is a common beginner confusion.

evidence.snippet: if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: Uses '&' to combine two boolean comparisons, suggesting a misunderstanding of the usual '&&' logical AND operator.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Confusion between Logical AND (&&) and Bitwise AND (&)
misconceptions.description: The student uses the bitwise AND operator (`&`) instead of the logical AND operator (`&&`) to combine two boolean conditions in the `if` statement. While functionally identical when applied to boolean operands in this context, `&&` is the standard logical operator that provides short-circuiting behavior.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes `&` is always the correct or equivalent operator for logical conjunction in conditional statements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The logical AND operator in Java is `&&`. It is generally preferred because it short-circuits, meaning the second operand is not evaluated if the first operand is false.
symptoms: Use of single ampersand in conditional statement
misconceptions.root_cause: Misremembering or confusing the syntax for logical operators.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use the double ampersand (`&&`) for combining boolean conditions in `if` statements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The usage is explicit in the code.

evidence.snippet: if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: Uses '&' (bitwise AND) instead of '&&' (logical AND).

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Uses bitwise & instead of logical && in conditional
misconceptions.description: The condition is written as `grade >= 80 & grade < 90` using the single `&` operator. In Java, `&` between booleans is a non-short-circuiting logical AND (also used as bitwise AND for integers), whereas `&&` is the conventional short-circuiting logical AND for boolean expressions in conditions. While in this specific context both will yield the same truth value, using `&` here suggests a misunderstanding of the intended operator for compound boolean conditions.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that `&` is the correct or interchangeable operator for combining boolean conditions in an `if` statement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java conditionals, `&&` is the standard operator for combining boolean expressions with logical AND and it short-circuits, evaluating the right-hand side only when necessary. The single `&` is primarily used either as a bitwise operator on integer types or as a non-short-circuiting boolean AND, and is rarely appropriate in simple range checks.
symptoms: The conditional uses `grade >= 80 & grade < 90` instead of `grade >= 80 && grade < 90`.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between bitwise and logical operators or assumption that a single ampersand is sufficient for logical AND in Java conditions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use `&&` when you want to combine boolean comparisons in an `if` condition, e.g., `if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90)`.
related_concepts: Logical vs bitwise operators in Java
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The use of `&` in a typical range check is a common beginner mistake indicating confusion between `&` and `&&`.

evidence.snippet: if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: This condition uses `&` instead of the usual short-circuit logical operator `&&` for combining comparisons.

misconceptions.description: Student uses the bitwise AND operator (&) instead of the logical AND operator (&&) in a conditional statement. While & may work in some contexts, it is semantically incorrect for boolean logic and doesn't short-circuit like &&.

misconceptions.correct_understanding: In conditional statements, use && (logical AND) to combine boolean expressions. The && operator returns a single true/false value and uses short-circuit evaluation. The & operator is bitwise AND and operates on individual bits—it should not be used in boolean conditions.

Only one grade range is checked instead of all five
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators and logical operators; insufficient understanding of Java operator semantics.

evidence.note: Bitwise AND (&) is used instead of logical AND (&&). In conditional statements, && should always be used to combine boolean expressions.
